Class GlobalLink

If enabled, this class provides constructors for all of the types in the library without needing to fully qualify the type. Using this is completely optional, but does create very clean looking code.

Inheritance
System.Object
GlobalLink
Namespace: FunctionalLink.Next
Assembly: FunctionalLink.Next.dll
Syntax
public static class GlobalLink : Object
Remarks

To enable this feature, make a static using statement like so:

using static FunctionalLink.Next.GlobalLink;

Once enabled, you can construct Options and Results with less code. e.g.:

return value != null
    ? Some(value); 
    : None();

return found
    ? Success(value); 
    : Failure("Value not found");

Methods

Failure<T>(T)

This is an alternate constructor for a Result in a failure state.

Declaration
public static Failure<T> Failure<T>(T failure)
Parameters
Type Name Description
T failure

The failure value
Returns
Type Description
Failure<T>

A Failure that implicitly converts to a Result
Type Parameters
Name Description
T

The failure value type
Remarks

The implicit conversion allows you to declare a successful result with less type information. e.g.

public static Result<int> Divide(int a, int b) =>
    return b != 0
        ? Success(a / b)
        : Failure("Cannot divide by 0");

Without the implicit conversion, the code would look like this:

public static Result<int> Divide(int a, int b) =>
    return b != 0
        ? Option<int>.Success(a / b)
        : Option<int>.Failure("Cannot divide by 0");

This is purely an aesthetic choice. Both implementations yield the same result.

Maybe<T>(T)

This is an alternate constructor for creating an Option from an unknown nullable value.

Declaration
public static Option<T> Maybe<T>(T value)
Parameters
Type Name Description
T value

The target value
Returns
Type Description
Option<T>

An Option in the Some state if value is not null. Otherwise in the None state
Type Parameters
Name Description
T

The target value type
Remarks

These are equivalent constructors:

value.Maybe();
Maybe(value);
Option.Maybe(value);
Option<int>.Maybe(value);

None()

This is an alternate constructor for creating an Option in a None state.

Declaration
public static None None()
Returns
Type Description
None

An Option in a None state
Remarks

These are equivalent constructors:

None();
Option.None();
Option<int>.None();

Self<T>(T)

A self referencing function. A function that returns the entity passed to it.

Declaration
public static T Self<T>(T value)
Parameters
Type Name Description
T value

The target value
Returns
Type Description
T

The given value unmodified
Type Parameters
Name Description
T

The type of the target value
Remarks

This is often useful in Linq statements. You can replace this:

var result = values.GroupBy(i => i);

with

var result = values.GroupBy(Self);

It's largely an aesthetic choice. But technically you are not reimplementing (i => i) over and over. This is also positive.

Remarks

These are equivalent constructors:

Option.Some(123);
Option<int>.Some(123);

Success()

An alternate constructor for a Result in a success state, but with no particular value to return.
